Point of no return.<[silence:500]> Space’s ultimate trapdoor.<[silence:500]>

The name comes from ships at sea:<[silence:400]> the event horizon is the line where waves vanish from view—and in space, it’s where light itself can’t escape.<[silence:500]>

Black holes don’t suck things in like a vacuum.<[silence:500]> They’re more like a waterfall’s edge.<[silence:500]> Swim too close, and the current pulls you over.<[silence:500]> Past the event horizon, the river flows faster than you can paddle—even light, the universe’s speed champion, gets dragged under.<[silence:500]>

Imagine a flashlight beam aimed outward.<[silence:500]> Outside the horizon, the light streaks away.<[silence:500]> At the horizon, it freezes—stretched into invisibility.<[silence:500]> Inside, it never reaches your eyes.<[silence:500]> The black hole’s gravity warps time so severely that, to an outside observer, you’d appear to slow, then halt, then fade like a dying ember.<[silence:500]> <[silence:500]>

Records show the first real image of an event horizon (M87, 2019) took a telescope the size of Earth.<[silence:500]> The black hole’s shadow was 2.5 times wider than the horizon itself—a cosmic mirage, bending light into a ring.<[silence:500]>

Gravity’s blind spot.<[silence:500]> Time’s final tick.<[silence:500]> The universe’s delete key.<[silence:500]>
